pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:0.3: The chapter on offenses entailing confession
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:0.5: 2. The training rule on abusive speech
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:1.1.1: At one time when the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:1.1.2: the monks from the group of six were arguing with and speaking abusively to the good monks.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:1.1.3: They reviled and insulted them about their caste, name, family, occupation, profession, illnesses, physical traits, defilements, and offenses, and by calling them names.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:1.1.4: The monks of few desires complained and criticized them,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:1.1.5: “How can the monks from the group of six argue with and abuse good monks?
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:1.1.6: How can they revile and insult them about these things?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:1.1.7: After rebuking those monks in many ways, they told the Buddha. Soon afterwards he had the Sangha gathered and questioned the monks:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:1.1.8: “Is it true, monks, that you’re doing this?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:1.1.11: “Foolish men, how can you do this?
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:1.1.15: he gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:1.2.1: “Once upon a time, monks, there was a brahmin in Takkasilā who had an ox called Nandivisāla.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:1.2.2: On one occasion the ox said to that brahmin,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:1.2.3: ‘Go, brahmin, and bet a thousand coins with the wealthy merchant that your ox will pull one hundred carts tied together.’
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:1.2.5: And that brahmin did just that.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:1.2.7: Then, after tying one hundred carts together and yoking Nandivisāla to them, he said,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:1.2.10: Then that brahmin became depressed because he had lost a thousand coins.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:1.2.13: ‘Because I lost one thousand coins because of you.’
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:1.2.14: ‘But why did you disgrace me by calling me a fraud when I’m not?
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:1.2.15: Now go, brahmin, and make the same bet with that merchant, but increase the stakes to two thousand coins.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:1.2.17: Just don’t disgrace me by calling me a fraud.’
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:1.2.18: Once again that brahmin did just that.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:1.2.20: Then, after tying one hundred carts together and yoking Nandivisāla to them, he said,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:1.2.22: And Nandivisāla pulled those one hundred carts.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:1.2.28: And he was delighted with that.’
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:1.2.29: Even at that time, monks, reviling and insulting was unpleasant to me.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:1.2.30: How then could reviling and insulting be pleasant now?
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:1.2.32: “And, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:1.2.33.1: ‘If a monk speaks abusively, he commits an offense entailing confession.’”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:2.1.2: he speaks abusively in ten ways: about caste, about name, about family, about occupation, about profession, about illnesses, about physical traits, about defilements, about offenses, and by name-calling.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:2.1.4: there are two kinds of castes: low castes and high castes.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:2.1.6: outcasts, bamboo workers, hunters, carriage makers, waste removers—these are called “low castes”.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:2.1.8: aristocrats and brahmins—these are called “high castes”.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:2.1.10: there are two kinds of names: low names and high names.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:2.1.12: Avakaṇṇaka, Javakaṇṇaka, Dhaniṭṭhaka, Saviṭṭhaka, Kulavaḍḍhaka, or names, in whatever countries, that are despised, looked down upon, scorned, treated with contempt, disregarded—these are called “low names”.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:2.1.14: those connected with the Buddha, connected with the Teaching, or connected with the Sangha, or names, in whatever countries, that are highly regarded, highly thought of, respected, valued, esteemed—these are called “high names”.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:2.1.16: there are two kinds of families: low families and high families.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:2.1.18: the Kosiya family, the Bhāradvāja family, or families, in whatever countries, that are despised, looked down upon, scorned, treated with contempt, disregarded—these are called “low families”.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:2.1.20: the Gotama family, the Moggallāna family, the Kaccāna family, the Vāsiṭṭha family, or families, in whatever countries, that are highly regarded, highly thought of, respected, valued, esteemed—these are called “high families”.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:2.1.22: there are two kinds of occupations: low occupations and high occupations.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:2.1.24: carpentry, waste removing, or occupations, in whatever countries, that are despised, looked down upon, scorned, treated with contempt, disregarded—these are called “low occupations”.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:2.1.26: farming, trade, cattle keeping, or occupations, in whatever countries, that are highly regarded, highly thought of, respected, valued, esteemed—these are called “high occupations”.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:2.1.28: there are two kinds of professions: low professions and high professions.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:2.1.30: reed work, pottery, weaving, leather work, hairdressing, or professions, in whatever countries, that are despised, looked down upon, scorned, treated with contempt, disregarded—these are called “low professions”.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:2.1.32: accounting, arithmetic, writing, or professions, in whatever countries, that are highly regarded, highly thought of, respected, valued, esteemed—these are called “high professions”.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:2.1.34: all are low, but there is the illness of diabetes which is high.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:2.1.36: there are two kinds of physical traits: low physical traits and high physical traits.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:2.1.38: too tall, too short, too dark, too fair—these are called “low physical traits”.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:2.1.40: not too tall, not too short, not too dark, not too fair—these are called “high physical traits”.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:2.1.44: all are low, but there is the attainment of stream-entry which is high.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:2.1.46: there are two kinds of name-calling: low name-calling and high name-calling.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:2.1.48: “You’re a camel,” “You’re a ram,” “You’re an ox,” “You’re a donkey,” “You’re an animal,” “You’re bound for hell;” “You’re not going to a good destination,” “You can only expect a bad destination,” or adding disparaging endings to someone’s name, or calling someone words for the male or female genitals—this is called “low name-calling”.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:2.1.50: “You’re wise,” “You’re competent,” “You’re intelligent,” “You’re learned,” “You’re an expounder of the Teaching;” “You’re not going to a bad destination,” “You can only expect a good destination”—this is called “high name-calling”.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:2.2.1: If one who is fully ordained, wishing to revile, wishing to insult, wishing to humiliate another who is fully ordained, says what is low to one who is low—an outcast, a bamboo worker, a hunter, a carriage maker, a waste remover—saying, “You’re an outcast,” “You’re a bamboo worker,” “You’re a hunter,” “You’re a carriage maker,” “You’re a waste remover,” then for every statement, he commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:2.2.2: If one who is fully ordained, wishing to revile, wishing to insult, wishing to humiliate another who is fully ordained, says what is low to one who is high—an aristocrat, a brahmin—saying, “You’re an outcast,” “You’re a bamboo worker,” “You’re a hunter,” “You’re a carriage maker,” “You’re a waste remover,” then for every statement, he commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:2.2.3: If one who is fully ordained, wishing to revile, wishing to insult, wishing to humiliate another who is fully ordained, says what is high to one who is low—an outcast, a bamboo worker, a hunter, a carriage maker, a waste remover—saying, “You’re an aristocrat,” “You’re a brahmin,” then for every statement, he commits an offense entailing confession.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:2.2.9: If one who is fully ordained, wishing to revile, wishing to insult, wishing to humiliate another who is fully ordained, says what is high to one who is high—a Buddharakkhita, a Dhammarakkhita, a Sangharakkhita—saying, “You’re a Buddharakkhita,” “You’re a Dhammarakkhita,” “You’re a Sangharakkhita,” then for every statement, he commits an offense entailing confession.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:2.2.19.1: If one who is fully ordained, wishing to revile, wishing to insult, wishing to humiliate another who is fully ordained, says what is low to one who is low—a reed worker, a potter, a weaver, a leather worker, a barber—saying, “You’re a reed worker,” “You’re a potter,” “You’re a weaver,” “You’re a leather worker,” “You’re a barber,” then for every statement, he commits an offense entailing confession.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:2.2.23.1: If one who is fully ordained, wishing to revile, wishing to insult, wishing to humiliate another who is fully ordained, says what is low to one who is low—a leper, one with abscesses, one with mild leprosy, one with tuberculosis, an epileptic—saying, “You’re a leper,” “You have abscesses,” “You have mild leprosy,” “You have tuberculosis,” “You’re an epileptic,” then for every statement, he commits an offense entailing confession.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:2.2.27.1: If one who is fully ordained, wishing to revile, wishing to insult, wishing to humiliate another who is fully ordained, says what is low to one who is low—one who is too tall, one who is too short, one who is too dark, one who is too fair—saying, “You’re too tall,” “You’re too short,” “You’re too dark,” “You’re too fair,” then for every statement, he commits an offense entailing confession.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:2.2.35.1: If one who is fully ordained, wishing to revile, wishing to insult, wishing to humiliate another who is fully ordained, says what is low to one who is low—one who has committed an offense entailing expulsion, one who has committed an offense entailing suspension, one who has committed a serious offense, one who has committed an offense entailing confession, one who has committed an offense entailing acknowledgment, one who has committed an offense of wrong conduct, one who has committed an offense of wrong speech—saying, “You’ve committed an offense entailing expulsion,” “You’ve committed an offense entailing suspension,” “You’ve committed a serious offense,” “You’ve committed an offense entailing confession,” “You’ve committed an offense entailing acknowledgment,” “You’ve committed an offense of wrong conduct,” “You’ve committed an offense of wrong speech,” then for every statement, he commits an offense entailing confession.
